pullRequest.body:
Nobeling's theorem: the Z-module of locally constant maps from a profinite set to the integers is free.

-  [x] depends on: #6360 
-  [x] depends on: #6373 
-  [x] depends on: #6395 
-  [x] depends on: #6396

nodes.body: The nine PRs that have been merged, that this one depends on, contain all the stuff that I could find that was of independent interest. I think the stuff in the `NobelingProof` namespace will never be used outside this proof. But I could split this file into smaller ones, maybe create a `Nobeling` folder inside `Profinite`?
Hmm, if nothing else can be split out, it doesn't really make sense to split the file.
@jcommelin #7895, #7896, #7897 and #7899 are some general lemmas about lists that I extracted according to your suggestions.

I can't figure out how to make CI happy with these `continuity? says` statements. It produces a useless `rename_i` statement that CI wants me to include, but if I do that then the unused variables linter complains.
This seems to be getting in a pretty good shape. There are still some open TODOs. Could you please take a look at those? (And merge master after the dependent PRs have been merged.)

Thanks for your comments Kevin! I'll look through them now and try to improve the overall documentation.
I've added lots of documentation and put everything in the `Profinite` namespace.

bors d+

This file is about 2000 lines... :open_mouth: 
Do you think there are some pieces that can be reused and hence split into other files?
line-by-line review of first 200ish lines
line-by-line comments of the next 200ish lines
line-by-line comments on the next 100ish lines
The next chunk. It's not completely polished, but it's a refactor in the right direction.
And another batch
And another batch
And another batch
A few more comments

Dagur I would really like to review this, but it's huge so I propose doing it in parts. I've got up to line 400 and so far it looks great. I really hope to have read to the end by Monday, but I need to do other things now and I'm slightly worried that someone will merge it before I'm done (it's clearly pretty much ready), so to make sure I've not wasted my time I'll post this partial review now, and will come back to this later.

OK I've looked at it all. It's a tour de force. I do wish there was tighter integration with a manuscript, or more comments guiding the reader what is happening in the proof. There are entire sections containing huge proofs with no explanation of what is going on in them. I would rather see a few more docstrings -- you are in a much better position to write them than me. Give the reader scrolling through the docs on the web some kind of overview.

Wow! Thanks for all that documentation. Massive improvement.

A few more minor nitpicks. But this is now very close to merging.

Thanks :tada: 

If CI passes, please remove the label `awaiting-CI` and merge this yourself, by adding a comment `bors r+`.

bors d+

`continuity` can prove this right after the `dsimp`. But it's a bit slowish, so we can cache the output of `continuity?`
```suggestion
  dsimp [Proj]
  continuity says
    apply continuous_pi
    intro i
    split
    · apply continuous_apply
    · apply continuous_const
```

```suggestion

    obtain ⟨z, hz, rfl⟩ := hy

    rw [proj_comp_of_subset J K h]
  · obtain ⟨y, hy, rfl⟩ := h
    dsimp [Set.proj]
    rw [← Set.image_comp]
    refine ⟨y, ⟨hy, ?_⟩⟩
    rw [proj_comp_of_subset J K h]
```

```suggestion
theorem one_sub_e_mem_of_false {x y : (Set.proj C (· ∈ J))} {a : I} (ha : y.val a = true)
    (hx : x.val a = false) : 1 - e (Set.proj C (· ∈ J)) a ∈ factors C J x := by
  simp only [factors, List.mem_map, Finset.mem_sort]
  use a
  simp only [hx, ite_false, and_true]
  rcases y with ⟨_, z, hz, rfl⟩
  simp only [Proj, Bool.ite_eq_true_distrib, if_false_right_eq_and] at ha
  exact ha.1
```

```suggestion
    refine ⟨1 - (e (C.proj (· ∈ J)) a), ⟨one_sub_e_mem_of_false _ _ ha hx, ?_⟩⟩
    rw [e, LocallyConstant.evalMonoidHom_apply, LocallyConstant.sub_apply,
      LocallyConstant.coe_one, Pi.one_apply, LocallyConstant.coe_mk, if_pos ha, sub_self]
  · refine ⟨e (C.proj (· ∈ J)) a, ⟨e_mem_of_eq_true _ _ hx, ?_⟩⟩
    rw [hx] at ha

```
This seems like a lemma that could move to a more general file.

```suggestion
-- TODO: this lemma is purely about lists, and should be moved to the appropriate API file
theorem GoodProducts.extracted_1
  (a : I) (as : List I) (ha : List.Chain' (fun x x_1 ↦ x > x_1) (a :: as))
  (m : List I) (hm : List.Chain' (fun x x_1 ↦ x > x_1) m)
  (hmas : m ≤ as) : List.Chain' (fun x x_1 ↦ x > x_1) (a :: m) := by
  cases m with
  | nil => simp only [List.chain'_singleton]
  | cons b bs =>
    apply hm.cons
    cases as with
    | nil =>
      simp only [le_iff_lt_or_eq, or_false] at hmas
      exact (List.Lex.not_nil_right (·<·) _ hmas).elim
    | cons a' as =>
      rw [List.chain'_cons] at ha
      refine gt_of_gt_of_ge ha.1 ?_
      rw [le_iff_lt_or_eq] at hmas
      cases' hmas with hmas hmas
      · by_contra' hh
        rw [← not_le] at hmas
        apply hmas
        apply le_of_lt
        exact (List.lt_iff_lex_lt _ _).mp (List.lt.head _ _ hh)
      · simp only [List.cons.injEq] at hmas
        rw [ge_iff_le, le_iff_lt_or_eq]
        exact Or.inr hmas.1

theorem GoodProducts.extracted_2
  (a : I) (as : List I) (ha : List.Chain' (fun x x_1 ↦ x > x_1) (a :: as)) (c : Products I →₀ ℤ)
  (hc : (c.support : Set (Products I)) ⊆ {m | m.val ≤ as})
  (hsm :
    ∀ (c : ℤ) (x : LocallyConstant ↑(Set.proj C fun x ↦ x ∈ J) ℤ),
      e (Set.proj C fun x ↦ x ∈ J) a * c • x = c • (e (Set.proj C fun x ↦ x ∈ J) a * x)) :
  (Finsupp.sum c fun a_1 b ↦ e (Set.proj C fun x ↦ x ∈ J) a * b • Products.eval (Set.proj C fun x ↦ x ∈ J) a_1) ∈
    Submodule.span ℤ (Products.eval (Set.proj C fun x ↦ x ∈ J) '' {m | m.val ≤ a :: as}) := by
  apply Submodule.finsupp_sum_mem
  intro m hm
  rw [hsm]
  apply Submodule.smul_mem
  apply Submodule.subset_span
  have hmas : m.val ≤ as
  · apply hc
    simpa only [Finset.mem_coe, Finsupp.mem_support_iff] using hm
  refine ⟨⟨a :: m.val, ?_⟩, ⟨?_, ?_⟩⟩
  · exact GoodProducts.extracted_1 _ _ ha m.val m.prop hmas
  · simp only [Set.mem_setOf_eq]
    -- TODO: the remaining proof in this subgoal could be extracted into an API lemma
    rw [le_iff_lt_or_eq] at hmas ⊢
    refine hmas.imp ?_ (congr_arg _)
    intro hmas
    have haa : ¬(a < a) := gt_irrefl a
    exact (List.lt_iff_lex_lt _ _).mp
      (List.lt.tail haa haa ((List.lt_iff_lex_lt _ _).mpr hmas))
  · simp only [Products.eval, List.map, List.prod_cons]

theorem GoodProducts.spanFin : ⊤ ≤ Submodule.span ℤ (Set.range (eval (C.proj (· ∈ J)))) := by
  rw [span_iff_products]
  refine le_trans (spanFinBasis.span C J) ?_
  rw [Submodule.span_le]
  intro _ ⟨x, hrfl⟩; cases hrfl -- TODO: why does `intro` not accept a `rfl` pattern here?
  rw [← factors_prod_eq_basis]
  let l := J.sort (·≥·)
  dsimp [factors]
  suffices : l.Chain' (·>·) → (l.map (fun i ↦ if x.val i = true then e (C.proj (· ∈ J)) i
      else (1 - (e (C.proj (· ∈ J)) i)))).prod ∈
      Submodule.span ℤ ((Products.eval (C.proj (· ∈ J))) '' {m | m.val ≤ l})
  · exact Submodule.span_mono (Set.image_subset_range _ _) (this (Finset.sort_chain'_gt _))
  induction l with
  | nil =>
    intro _
    apply Submodule.subset_span
    exact ⟨⟨[], List.chain'_nil⟩,⟨Or.inl rfl, rfl⟩⟩
  | cons a as ih =>
    rw [List.map_cons, List.prod_cons]
    intro ha
    specialize ih (by rw [List.chain'_cons'] at ha; exact ha.2)
    rw [Finsupp.mem_span_image_iff_total] at ih
    simp only [Finsupp.mem_supported, Finsupp.total_apply] at ih
    obtain ⟨c, hc, hc'⟩ := ih
    rw [← hc']; clear hc'
    have hmap := fun g ↦ map_finsupp_sum (LinearMap.mulLeft ℤ (e (C.proj (· ∈ J)) a)) c g
    have hsm := (LinearMap.mulLeft ℤ (e (C.proj (· ∈ J)) a)).map_smul
    dsimp at hsm hmap ⊢
    split_ifs
    · rw [hmap]
      exact GoodProducts.extracted_2 _ _ _ _ ha _ hc hsm
    · ring_nf
      rw [hmap]
      apply Submodule.add_mem
      · apply Submodule.neg_mem
        exact GoodProducts.extracted_2 _ _ _ _ ha _ hc hsm
      · apply Submodule.finsupp_sum_mem
        intro m hm
        apply Submodule.smul_mem
        apply Submodule.subset_span
        refine ⟨m, ⟨?_, rfl⟩⟩
        simp only [Set.mem_setOf_eq]
        have hmas : m.val ≤ as :=
          hc (by simpa only [Finset.mem_coe, Finsupp.mem_support_iff] using hm)
        refine le_trans hmas ?_
        cases as with
        | nil => exact (List.nil_lt_cons a []).le
        | cons b bs =>
          apply le_of_lt
          rw [List.chain'_cons] at ha
          have hlex := List.lt.head bs (b :: bs) ha.1
          exact (List.lt_iff_lex_lt _ _).mp hlex
```

```suggestion
theorem Products.prop_of_isGood_of_contained  {l : Products I} (o : Ordinal) (h : l.isGood C)
    (hsC : contained C o) (i : I) (hi : i ∈ l.val) : ord I i < o := by
  by_contra h'
  apply h
  suffices : eval C l = 0
  · simp [this, Submodule.zero_mem]
  ext x
  simp only [eval_eq, LocallyConstant.coe_zero, Pi.zero_apply, ite_eq_right_iff, one_ne_zero]
  contrapose! h'
  exact hsC x.val x.prop i (h'.1 i hi)
```

```suggestion
  rw [ModuleCat.exact_iff]
  ext f
  rw [LinearMap.mem_ker, LinearMap.mem_range]
```

```suggestion
  · by_cases hh : term I ho ∈ l.val
    · exact Or.inr ⟨h, hh⟩
    · left
      intro he
      apply h
      have h' := Products.prop_of_isGood_of_contained C _ h hsC
      simp only [Order.lt_succ_iff] at h'
      simp only [not_imp_not] at hh

      · intro a ha
        refine (h' a ha).lt_of_ne ?_

        contradiction

  · refine h.elim (fun hh ↦ ?_) And.left

    rwa [contained_eq_proj C (Order.succ o) hsC]
```

```suggestion
    LinearMap.sub_apply, LinearMap.coe_mk, AddHom.coe_mk, LocallyConstant.sub_apply,
    continuous_CC'₀, continuous_CC'₁, LocallyConstant.coe_comap, LocallyConstant.coe_mul,
    Function.comp_apply, Pi.mul_apply]
  rw [CC'₁, CC'₀, Products.eval_eq, Products.eval_eq, Products.eval_eq]
  simp only [mul_ite, mul_one, mul_zero]
  have hi' : ∀ i, i ∈ l.Tail.val → (x.val i = SwapTrue o x.val i)
  · intro i hi
    simp only [SwapTrue, @eq_comm _ (x.val i), ite_eq_right_iff, ord_term ho]
    rintro rfl
    exact ((List.Chain.rel hlc hi).ne rfl).elim
  have H :
    (∀ i, i ∈ l.Tail.val → (x.val i = true)) = (∀ i, i ∈ l.Tail.val → (SwapTrue o x.val i = true))
  · apply forall_congr; intro i; apply forall_congr; intro hi; rw [hi' i hi]
  simp only [H]

  · push_neg at h₂; obtain ⟨i, hi⟩ := h₂; exfalso; rw [hi' i hi.1] at hi; exact hi.2 (h₁ i hi.1)
  · push_neg at h₁; obtain ⟨i, hi⟩ := h₁; exfalso; rw [← hi' i hi.1] at hi; exact hi.2 (h₃ i hi.1)
```

```suggestion
a product of `I` copies of `Bool` for some sufficiently large `I`, and then to choose a
well-ordering on `I` and use ordinal induction over that well-order. Here we can let `I` be
the set of clopen subsets of `S` since `S` is totally separated.
```

I don't like "to embed" and then "choosing/using" -- I think it should be "to choose" and then "to use".

If the reference is already in the .bib file, then should it be mentioned here again in a less precise way? (i.e. without the URL?) Is it better to remove this line completely, rather than making the reader believe that this less precise reference is all they're going to get?

Hmm, maybe the correct thing to do is something like
```suggestion
- [scholze2019condensed], Theorem 5.4.
```
Then it's clear that `[scholze2019condensed]` is a pointer to the `.bib` file, and we give a precise ref to the theorem.
I am always confused about whether this should be `dsimp only [Proj]` or not. Are non-terminal dsimps considered harmful? Does it depend on who you ask?
non-terminal dsimps are much less harmful then non-terminal simps. They aren't 100% safe, but they are certainly considered safe enough to be allowed in mathlib.

```suggestion
  Set.surjective_mapsTo_image_restrict _ _
```
We do have this lemma in mathlib already, but its name is so long that it's barely any saving on the direct proof :-)

```suggestion
  refine ⟨fun ⟨y, hy, h⟩ ↦ ?_, fun h ↦ ⟨x, h, ?_⟩⟩
  · rwa [← h, proj_eq_self]; exact (hh · y hy)
  · rw [proj_eq_self]; exact (hh · x h)
```
I never quite know when it's justified to have `tac1; tac2; tac3` lines instead of writing things on three lines. But by doing more deconstructing in the `refine` line you can get them both down to 2.

If I change this to `aesop?` then I get "Suggestion Error: TypeError: Cannot read properties of undefined" which is unexpected, and a PANIC. Is this a known issue? Note to self: minimise, check it's happening on master, and ask on Zulip after reviewing this PR.
(I did this)

```suggestion
obtain ⟨y, ⟨z, hz, rfl⟩, rfl⟩ := h
```
This syntax works recursively.

```suggestion
    refine ⟨z, hz, (?_ : _ = (Proj J ∘ Proj K) z)⟩ 
```
You can also do it like this (if you want). Note that the pointy bracket syntax is right associative, so `exact ⟨z, ⟨hz, this⟩⟩` can be `exact ⟨z, hz, this⟩`

```suggestion
    refine ⟨y, hy, ?_⟩
```

```suggestion
/-- For a given compact subset `C` of `I → Bool`, `spanFunctor` is the functor from
the poset of finsets of `I` to `Profinite`, sending a finite subset set `J` to the
image of `C` in `J → Bool`. -/
```
Have I got this right? I didn't understand your docstring. And do you mean to assume that `I` is linearly ordered in this definition? Because, for some reason, it is. However given that much of this code will
probably not be reused, perhaps this doesn't matter?

```suggestion
/-- The limit cone on `spanFunctor` with point `C`. -/
```

nodes.body:
This file is about 2000 lines... :open_mouth: 
Do you think there are some pieces that can be reused and hence split into other files?

The nine PRs that have been merged, that this one depends on, contain all the stuff that I could find that was of independent interest. I think the stuff in the `NobelingProof` namespace will never be used outside this proof. But I could split this file into smaller ones, maybe create a `Nobeling` folder inside `Profinite`?
Hmm, if nothing else can be split out, it doesn't really make sense to split the file.
line-by-line review of first 200ish lines
line-by-line comments of the next 200ish lines

The next chunk. It's not completely polished, but it's a refactor in the right direction.
And another batch
And another batch
And another batch
@jcommelin #7895, #7896, #7897 and #7899 are some general lemmas about lists that I extracted according to your suggestions.
A few more comments

I can't figure out how to make CI happy with these `continuity? says` statements. It produces a useless `rename_i` statement that CI wants me to include, but if I do that then the unused variables linter complains.
This seems to be getting in a pretty good shape. There are still some open TODOs. Could you please take a look at those? (And merge master after the dependent PRs have been merged.)

Dagur I would really like to review this, but it's huge so I propose doing it in parts. I've got up to line 400 and so far it looks great. I really hope to have read to the end by Monday, but I need to do other things now and I'm slightly worried that someone will merge it before I'm done (it's clearly pretty much ready), so to make sure I've not wasted my time I'll post this partial review now, and will come back to this later.

OK I've looked at it all. It's a tour de force. I do wish there was tighter integration with a manuscript, or more comments guiding the reader what is happening in the proof. There are entire sections containing huge proofs with no explanation of what is going on in them. I would rather see a few more docstrings -- you are in a much better position to write them than me. Give the reader scrolling through the docs on the web some kind of overview.
Thanks for your comments Kevin! I'll look through them now and try to improve the overall documentation.
I've added lots of documentation and put everything in the `Profinite` namespace.

Wow! Thanks for all that documentation. Massive improvement.

A few more minor nitpicks. But this is now very close to merging.

Thanks :tada: 

If CI passes, please remove the label `awaiting-CI` and merge this yourself, by adding a comment `bors r+`.

bors d+
